title: Thermal energy transfer - three gases in container

content.question: A container with three sections initially contains samples of three different monatomic ideal gases, which are separated by removable barriers, as shown. The container is thermally isolated from its surroundings. The masses of gas atoms in gases <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> are <math alttext="m sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="m sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, respectively, where <math alttext="m sub A is greater than m sub B, which is greater than m sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. The initial temperatures gases <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> are <math alttext="T sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="T sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, respectively, where <math alttext="T sub C is greater than T sub B, which is greater than T sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Both barriers are removed at the same time and the gases mix. Which of the following statements about the average kinetic energy of the gas atoms after the barriers are removed must be true?

choices.label: The average kinetic energy of Gas <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> atoms will increase.
The average kinetic energy of Gas <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> atoms will not change.
The average kinetic energy of Gas <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> atoms will increase.
The average kinetic energy of Gas <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> atoms will not change.

content.answer: The average kinetic energy of Gas <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> atoms will increase.
